s56.message: Exception rules are built the same as blocking rules, they define which addresses should be allowed even if matching blocking rules exists.

s54.message: The page loading it comes from {1} domain (for example {2} itself or {3}) but not from {4} or its subdomains.

s53.message: This address is being loaded as a script or an image.

s52.message: This rule blocks {1} only if the following conditions are met:

s50.message: Domain option restricts the filter to a set of domains (here example.com). It also allows to disable the rule on some domains (here on foo.example.com).

s59.message: Rules starting like this are exceptions, they will override blocking rules.

abp-properties-purpose.message: Select an element if its CSS style properties match what's specified. You can pass a regular expression by surrounding it with "/".

s81.message: An exclamation mark at the beginning of the rule indicates a comment.

s106.message: {1} is used as a placeholder for element selectors.

abp-properties-example1.message: By using a wildcard *, this filter matches an img whose CSS style properties have a width specified in pixels and a height of 250 pixels

s101.message: Specify whether a filter should be active on third-party or first domains

s102.message: Less frequently used options, including {1}, {2}, {3}, {4}, {5} and {6} are explained in the Writing Adblock Plus Filters documentation.

abp-properties-example2.message: By using a regular expression, this filter matches an img whose CSS style properties have a width between 32 and 38 pixels

s44.message: This part of the rule defines which addresses it is applied to.

s46.message: This character indicates that the following text defines filter option.

s42.message: Blocking rules can have a number of options to fine-tune their behavior.

s83.message: This text will not be used for blocking, you can write anything you want.

s48.message: Type options define request types to be blocked. Common type options are script or image indicating that only scripts/images should be blocked. The inverse type option ~script means that the filter should not be applied to scripts.

s100.message: Specify a list of domains, separated by bar lines (|), on which a filter should be active. A filter may be prevented from being activated on a domain by preceding the domain name with a tilde (~).

abp-contains-example1.message: Matches {1} elements that have a direct descendent {2} element containing the text "Advertisment"

s74.message: This special type option indicates that Adblock Plus should be completely disabled on pages that this rule applies to.

s19.message: The following text must be the domain name of the address.

s10.message: The address must either end here or a separator character like ? or / has to follow.

s93.message: Include or exclude content handled by browser plug-ins like Flash or Java

s97.message: Used to whitelist the page itself (e.g. {1})

s95.message: Include or exclude pages loaded within pages (frames)

s94.message: Include or exclude files loaded by browser plug-ins

s98.message: Used to prevent element rules from applying on a page (e.g. {1})

s128.message: Matches the element with the unique id "advert"

s68.message: Example 2: Exception for an entire site

s63.message: This type option prevents the exception from being applied to scripts.

s61.message: This part of the rule defines which addresses it is applied to, it is structured the same as for blocking rules.

s135.message: Matches links to any pages hosted on http://example.com/

s134.message: Matches elements with the class "link" that are immediately preceded by elements with the id "advert"

s137.message: Matches div elements that end the style specified

s136.message: Matches div elements that start with the style specified

s130.message: Matches a table with a height of 100 and a width of 100

s133.message: Matches elements with the class "link" that are enclosed within elements with the id "advert"

s132.message: Matches div elements that have exactly the style specified

s139.message: The above filters are examples of valid element hiding rules. Any CSS selector supported by your browser can be used for element hiding.

s138.message: Matches div elements that containing the style specified

abp-has-purpose.message: Select an element if its content subtree match the selector specified

abp-contains-purpose.message: Select an element if its text content contains the specified string

s35.message: The preceding text must be the end of the address.

s31.message: The following text must be the beginning of the address.

s140.message: Include or exclude requests started using the XMLHttpRequest object or fetch API

s141.message: Include or exclude requests initiated via WebSocket object

s142.message: Include or exclude connections opened via RTCPeerConnection instances to ICE servers

s143.message: Include pages opened in a new tab or window

s144.message: Used to prevent applying global element rules on a page (e.g. @@||example.com^$generichide)

s145.message: Used to prevent applying global blocking rules on a page (e.g. @@||example.com^$genericblock)

abp-pseudo-select-2.message: When writing element hiding filters that make use those you must use the #?# syntax (replace ## with #?#) and take care to specify one or more domains. Some examples:

s8.message: This stands for any number of characters.

s3.message: Blocking rules determine addresses that Adblock Plus should block.

s6.message: This text must be present in the address to be blocked.

abp-pseudo-select-1.message: In some situations standard CSS selectors are not sufficient, for those cases you can also use the following Adblock Plus specific pseudo-selectors:

rewritedesc.message: Specify a rewrite rule for the URL to be performed before downloading. If the filter is a regular expression, use {1} to insert submatches into the rewritten URL. See JavaScript own {2}.

abp-properties-example.message: Matches {1} elements whose style contain the specified properties

abp-has-example3.message: Since the CSS properties are matched case-insensitively, this filter matches the same thing as above

abp-has-example2.message: Matches {1} elements that contain as a direct descendant a {2} element whose direct descendant is an {3} element whose style properties contain the specified properties, a {4} of 300 pixels and an {5} of 250 pixels

abp-has-example1.message: Matches {1} elements that contain as a direct descendant a {2} element whose direct descendant is an {3} with the class "advert"

s23.message: A separator character has to follow that will indicate the end of the domain name, e.g. / or :.
